elements.content: Three novel metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), |(C3H7NO)2(H2O)|[Zn3(C10H5N3O4)3(C3H7NO)2] (1), |(H2O)5(H3O)(NO3)|[Nd2(C10H5N3O4)3(H2O)4] (2), and |(H2O)2|[Nd3(C10H5N3O4)3(C10H4N3O4)] (3), based on the T-shaped tripodal ligands 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid and 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3PyImDC), have been constructed under solvo-/hydrothermal conditions. The diverse coordination modes of H3PyImDC ligands have afforded the assembly of three novel compounds. In compound 1, two oxygen atoms and three nitrogen atoms of the H3PyImDC ligand, a T-shaped linker, coordinate to two zinc centers to form a novel bbm net with two distinct channels along the [100] and [001] directions. In compound 2, H3PyImDC ligands coordinate to neodymium centers to form a ladder-like chain which then interacts with a water molecules chain via hydrogen-bondings to construct a 3D supermolecular structure. In compound 3, H3PyImDC ligands, a T-shaped linker, coordinate to neodymium centers to form a (3,6)-connected net with an ant topology. In compounds 1−3, the two H3PyImDC ligands exhibit different coordination modes with zinc and neodymium centers, which afforded the expected structural diversity. Additionally, all three compounds exhibit strong fluorescence emissions in the solid state at room temperature.

The diverse coordination modes of H3PyImDC ligands have afforded the assembly of three novel compounds. In compounds 1-3, the two H3PyImDC ligands exhibit different coordination modes with zinc and neodymium centers, which afforded the expected structural diversity. Additionally, all three compounds exhibit strong fluorescence emissions in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: H3PyImDC, as a T-shaped linker with selective, nitrogen−oxygen chelating, directionality, and substrate-binding ability, assembled with zinc and neodymium ions to produce three novel frameworks. Metal organic materials with bbm and ant network topologies are synthesized.
elements.clean_text: H3PyImDC, as a T-shaped linker with selective, nitrogen-oxygen chelating, directionality, and substrate-binding ability, assembled with zinc and neodymium ions to produce three novel frameworks. Metal organic materials with bbm and ant network topologies are synthesized.

elements.content: MOFs, an emerging class of functional solid state materials, have bourgeoned in the past decade due to their unique hybrid character, exceptional tunable porosity, and potential logical assembly from molecular building blocks. The distinctive advantage of MOFs over traditional porous materials, i.e. inorganic zeolites or activated carbons, is the ability to rationally design and construct made-to-order porous material where desired pore shape, size, and functionality can be modularly tuned toward targeted applications. Our group, among others, has explored N-heterocyclic carboxylic acids based ligands, i.e. 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3ImDC), as rigid and directional bridging ligands for the construction of metal−organic materials (MOMs) and especially zeolite-like metal organic frameworks (ZMOFs). It is evident that functionalized H3ImDC ligand, at the 2-positon of the imidazole ring, with diverse substituent groups such as methyl, ethyl, or pyridyl, will permit the construction of new MOMs. Accordingly, our group has effectively employed H3ImDC derivatives for the construction of a 3D (4,4)-connected framework with a pts net from 2-EtImDC and two novel chiral frameworks with bmn and lcy-a nets from H3PyImDC. It is important to mention that, in the above compounds, 2-EtImDC and H3PyImDC present distinct coordination modes relative to the parent H3ImDC ligand. The 2-ethyl and 2-pyridyl groups induce a spatial effect on adjacent carboxylate groups, permitting diverse coordination modes of the bridging H3ImDC ligand. In addition, the H3PyImDC can successively be deprotonated to generate H2PyImDC−, HPyImDC2−, and PyImDC3− species, which can serve as 2-, 3-, and 4-connectors and thus will potentially permit access of new MOMs with unique features. To the best of our knowledge, limited H3PyImDC-based compounds were reported recently by other research groups and include three 0D clusters, five 2D layers, and five 3D frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

MOFs, an emerging class of functional solid state materials, have bourgeoned in the past decade due to their unique hybrid character, exceptional tunable porosity, and potential logical assembly from molecular building blocks. The distinctive advantage of MOFs over traditional porous materials, i.e. inorganic zeolites or activated carbons, is the ability to rationally design and construct made-to-order porous material where desired pore shape, size, and functionality can be modularly tuned toward targeted applications. Our group, among others, has explored N-heterocyclic carboxylic acids based ligands, i.e. 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3ImDC), as rigid and directional bridging ligands for the construction of metal-organic materials (MOMs) and especially zeolite-like metal organic frameworks (ZMOFs). It is evident that functionalized H3ImDC ligand, at the 2-positon of the imidazole ring, with diverse substituent groups such as methyl, ethyl, or pyridyl, will permit the construction of new MOMs. Accordingly, our group has effectively employed H3ImDC derivatives for the construction of a 3D (4,4)-connected framework with a pts net from 2-EtImDC and two novel chiral frameworks with bmn and lcy-a nets from H3PyImDC. It is important to mention that, in the above compounds, 2-EtImDC and H3PyImDC present distinct coordination modes relative to the parent H3ImDC ligand. The 2-ethyl and 2-pyridyl groups induce a spatial effect on adjacent carboxylate groups, permitting diverse coordination modes of the bridging H3ImDC ligand. In addition, the H3PyImDC can successively be deprotonated to generate H2PyImDC-, HPyImDC2-, and PyImDC3- species, which can serve as 2-, 3-, and 4-connectors and thus will potentially permit access of new MOMs with unique features. To the best of our knowledge, limited H3PyImDC-based compounds were reported recently by other research groups and include three 0D clusters, five 2D layers, and five 3D frameworks.

elements.content: Indeed, in this paper we report the construction of three novel MOMs from the two newly synthesized and pyridyl-functionalized H3ImDC ligands (H3PyImDC), 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid and 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid. H3PyImDC reactions with zinc and neodymium metal ions generated three novel MOFs: |(C3H7NO)2(H2O)|[Zn3(C10H5N3O4)3(C3H7NO)2] (1), |(H2O)5(H3O)(NO3)|[Nd2(C10H5N3O4)3(H2O)4] (2), and |(H2O)2|[Nd3(C10H5N3O4)3(C10H4N3O4)] (3). Single crystal X-ray structures were determined for the three compounds, and their thermal stability and fluorescence properties were assessed.

H3PyImDC reactions with zinc and neodymium metal ions generated three novel MOFs: |(C3H7NO)2(H2O)|[Zn3(C10H5N3O4)3(C3H7NO)2] (1), |(H2O)5(H3O)(NO3)|[Nd2(C10H5N3O4)3(H2O)4] (2), and |(H2O)2|[Nd3(C10H5N3O4)3(C10H4N3O4)] (3). Single crystal X-ray structures were determined for the three compounds, and their thermal stability and fluorescence properties were assessed.

elements.content: The 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid and 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid were prepared according to reported procedures. All other reagents were used as received, from commercial sources, without further purification. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku 2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Elemental analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Optima 3300Dv spectrometer. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded within the 400−4000 cm−1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C analyzer in air with heating rates of 10 °C min−1. Fluorescence spectra were collected on a Shimadzu RF-5301 PC spectrophotometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid and 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid were prepared according to reported procedures. All other reagents were used as received, from commercial sources, without further purification. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku 2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Elemental analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Optima 3300Dv spectrometer. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded within the 400-4000 cm-1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C analyzer in air with heating rates of 10 °C min-1. Fluorescence spectra were collected on a Shimadzu RF-5301 PC spectrophotometer at room temperature.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·4H2O (0.10 mmol), 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (0.05 mmol), piperazine [0.1 mL, 0.58 M in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF)], HNO3 (0.1 mL, 0.35 M in DMF), and 2 mL of DMF/H2O (1:1) was sealed in a 20 mL vial and heated at 115 °C for 8 h. Colorless block crystals were collected (63% yield based on Zn(NO3)2·4H2O). Elemental analysis (wt %) for 1. Calcd: C, 42.03; H, 3.78; N, 15.17; Zn, 16.35. Found: C, 41.96; H, 3.63; N, 15.34; Zn, 16.20. FT-IR (4000−600 cm−1): 3389, 3059, 1715, 1633, 1485, 1462, 1351, 1280, 1234, 1064, 1012, 940, 697.

Synthesis of Compound 1

elements.content: A mixture of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.18 mmol), 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (0.25 mmol), KOH (0.06 mL, 8.03 M in H2O), and 4 mL H2O was sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 140 °C for 96 h. Polyhedral pink crystals were collected (62% yield based on Nd(NO3)3·6H2O). Elemental analysis (wt %) for 2. Calcd: C, 29.41; H, 2.96; N, 11.43; Nd, 23.55. elements.content: The as-synthesized compounds 1−3 were insoluble in water and common organic solvents. The phase purity of as-synthesized samples was confirmed by the evident similarities between the calculated and the experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns (see Figure S1). The FT-IR spectra for compounds 1−3 are shown in Figure S2.

The phase purity of as-synthesized samples was confirmed by the evident similarities between the calculated and the experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns (see  Figure S1). The FT-IR spectra for compounds 1-3 are shown in  Figure S2.

elements.content: Crystallographic data for 1 were collected on a Bruker SMART-APEX CCD diffractometer while 2 and 3 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied by using SADABS. The structures were solved with direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligand and water molecules were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors or by geometrical restraints. It is noted that the hydrogen atoms were not added in compound 3, as the C4, C5, and O1W atoms are disordered. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre: CCDC 763927 for 1, 763928 for 2, and 763929 for 3. Data can be obtained free of charge upon request at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Crystal data and detailed data collection and refinement of 1−3 are summarized in Table . Topology information for compounds 1 and 3 was obtained using TOPOS 4.0. Detailed topological information and network tiling are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

Crystallographic data for 1 were collected on a Bruker SMART-APEX CCD diffractometer while 2 and 3 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied by using SADABS. The structures were solved with direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligand and water molecules were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors or by geometrical restraints. It is noted that the hydrogen atoms were not added in compound 3, as the C4, C5, and O1W atoms are disordered. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre: CCDC 763927 for 1, 763928 for 2, and 763929 for 3. Data can be obtained free of charge upon request at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Crystal data and detailed data collection and refinement of 1-3 are summarized in Table . Topology information for compounds 1 and 3 was obtained using TOPOS 4.0. Detailed topological information and network tiling are summarized in .

X-ray single-crystal structure analysis reveals that 1 is a 3D neutral framework with water and DMF as guest molecules. Selected bond distances and bond angles are summarized in . There are two crystallographic independent Zn(1) and Zn(2) atoms, and the Zn(1) assumes a distorted octahedral geometry as shown in Figure a, in which the metal center is coordinated by three nitrogen atoms and three oxygen atoms, ZnN3O3. One coordinated oxygen atom is from a DMF molecule, and the two other coordinated oxygen atoms are from HPyImDC2− ligands. Zn(1) serves as a 4-connected tetrahedral center and is connected to four other zinc centers via HPyImDC2− bridging ligands. The other independent zinc, Zn(2), is coordinated to three nitrogen and two oxygen atoms from three distinct HPyImDC2− ligands and adopts a trigonal bipyramidal geometry ZnN3O2, as shown in Figure b. Therefore, the Zn(2) atom can be regarded as a 4-connected quadrilateral center connecting four zinc centers via HPyImDC2− ligands. In each independent HPyImDC2− ligand, the pyridyl nitrogen atom coordinates to one zinc atom (Figure b) and the imidazoledicarboxylic groups chelate two zinc atoms in a bis-bidentate fashion through the one oxygen of the carboxylic group and one nitrogen atom of the imidazole ring. Additionally, two distinct zinc centers are connected through the T-shaped ligands to form a 3D open framework (Figure c). Consequently, the zinc centers in 1 can be regarded as 4-connected nodes, and the resulting structure of 1 is a (4,4)-connected bbm network (Figure d), with two different T sites and one unique tile [3.6.7.82] (Figure e and ). To the best of our knowledge, only one other compound with similar network topology has been reported and recognized in the RCSR database.

elements.content: Interestingly, the 3D framework, 1, contains two distinct channels: one is an elongated channel along the [001] direction as shown in Figure c, approximately 6 × 15 Å in diameter, and the other is the square channel along the [100] direction, approximately 6.5 × 4 Å in diameter (see Figure S4a). The uncoordinated DMF and water molecules reside in these channels. The total accessible free volume was estimated as 44.4% of the cell volume, using PLATON.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that compound 2 is a 3D supermolecular framework with ladder-like chains and water chains. Selected bond distances and bond angles are summarized in . The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Nd(1) and Nd(2) atoms (Figure a), both of which are 9-coordinated with nine oxygen atoms. Seven coordinated oxygen atoms are from the carboxylic group of three HPyImDC2− ligands, and the remaining oxygen atoms are from terminal water molecules. Each HPyImDC2− ligand acts as a bridging linker with all the oxygen atoms coordinating two neodymium centers. Therefore, two neodymium centers and three HPyImDC2− ligands can be regarded as a secondary building unit (SBU). The SBUs alternately connect to form a ladder-like chain with a HPyImDC2− ligand pointing toward the outer surface, as shown in Figure b. The water molecules are arranged in a distorted chain as O5W−O3W−O2W−O17−N10−O18−O6W−O4W−O1W, in which hydrogen-bondings transfer from O5W and O1W to the central N10 of the NO3 − ion to form a particular water chain (see Figure c and Figure S4b).

Crystal Structure of 2 

X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that compound 2 is a 3D supermolecular framework with ladder-like chains and water chains. Selected bond distances and bond angles are summarized in . The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Nd(1) and Nd(2) atoms (Figure a), both of which are 9-coordinated with nine oxygen atoms. Seven coordinated oxygen atoms are from the carboxylic group of three HPyImDC2- ligands, and the remaining oxygen atoms are from terminal water molecules. Each HPyImDC2- ligand acts as a bridging linker with all the oxygen atoms coordinating two neodymium centers. Therefore, two neodymium centers and three HPyImDC2- ligands can be regarded as a secondary building unit (SBU). The SBUs alternately connect to form a ladder-like chain with a HPyImDC2- ligand pointing toward the outer surface, as shown in Figure b. The water molecules are arranged in a distorted chain as O5W-O3W-O2W-O17-N10-O18-O6W-O4W-O1W, in which hydrogen-bondings transfer from O5W and O1W to the central N10 of the NO3 - ion to form a particular water chain (see Figure c and  Figure S4b).

elements.content: Interestingly, there are interactions between the water chain and the ladder-like chain; the water chain acts as a hydrogen-bonding donor and offers three hydrogen atoms of O1W, O2W, and O3W atoms to O12, N8, and O2 atoms of the ladder-like chain. On the other hand, the water chain acts as a hydrogen-bonding acceptor and receives three hydrogen atoms from O16, N1, and O14 atoms of the ladder-like chain. Consequently, the water chains and ladder-like chains interact with each other through hydrogen-bonding to construct a 3D supermolecular structure (Figure d and hydrogen bonding see ). It should be noted that one of the guest water molecules is protonated in order to balance the negative charge provided by the presence of nitrate anions.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that compound 3 is a 3D neutral with water as guest molecules. Selected bond distances and bond angles are summarized in . There are two crystallographically independent neodymium atoms in compound 3. Nd(1) is coordinated with two nitrogen and six oxygen atoms from three ligands and adopts a dodecahedral geometry NdN2O6 (Figure a). Accordingly, the Nd(1) atom serves as a 3-connected triangular node and connects three Nd(2) atoms via bridging ligands as shown in Figure a. The Nd(2) atom is coordinated to eight oxygen atoms from four different organic ligands and assumes a dodecahedral geometry NdO8, as shown in Figure b. Therefore, the Nd(2) atom can be regarded as a 6-connected octahedral node connecting six neodymium centers through the bridging oxygen atoms. It should be noted that the organic ligands are deprotonated and form HPyImDC2− and PyImDC3− species, both acting as T-shaped linkers with the entire oxygen atoms and one of the nitrogen atoms participating in chelating neodymium atoms to form a 3D open framework (Figure c). To better understand the structure of 3, the two neodymium centers can be regarded topologically as 3- and 6-connected nodes and thus lead to a three-periodic (3,6)-connected ant net, as shown in Figure d, with two different T sites and two distinct tiles: [83] and [42.82] (Figure e and ). This network topology has been observed previously in phosphates and limited MOF structures.

elements.content: Compared with the reported MOFs based on the 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid ligand, the organic ligand has displayed 8 types of coordination modes as seen in Figure a−g, including one 0D cluster in (a) coordination mode, five 2D layers in the (b), (c), and (d) coordination modes, and five 3D frameworks in the (b), (e), and (f) coordination modes. Favorably, when it acts as a T-shaped tripodal linker in the (f) mode with a zinc center, a 2D 3,8-connected layer network and a 3D bbm network in compound 1 have been generated, while with a copper center two chiral bmn and lcy-a networks formed, as we have reported. Therefore, the (f) mode is an ideal coordination mode for the ligand, as we have predefined. When it coordinates with the neodymium center in the (c) and (g) modes, it gives a ladder-like chain in compound 2. When it comes to the 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid ligand, it has rarely been concerned as a ligand for constructing MOFs. Up to now, there are two 0D clusters with magnesium and iron centers reported, and they serve as terminal ligand in the (h) coordination mode in two compounds (see Figure h−j), while, in compound 3, it connects neodymium centers in the (i) and (j) coordination modes to form a 3D ant network. Through the studies of the coordination modes of two H3PyImDC ligands, it is found that all or some of the oxygen/nitrogen atoms exhibit strong chelating ability, which have potential use for constructing more architecture by carefully choosing metal centers.

elements.content: The thermal stability of compounds 1−3 has been evaluated ( Figure S5). For compound 1, it shows the first mass loss of 1.41% below 143 °C that can be attributed to the removal of water molecules (calcd 1.50%). Upon further heating, a two-step weight loss was observed: an initial weight loss of 24.24% from 143 to 330 °C that can be associated with the release of DMF molecules. The second weight loss occurs between 330 and 600 °C (50.02%) and is attributed to partial organic ligand decomposition (calcd 57.78%). The final release at 800 °C of 20.95% is attributed to the formation of ZnO as confirmed by XRD analysis. Compounds 2−3 show similar thermal behaviors. The TG curves exhibit an initial weight loss finishing at 250 °C for 2 and 3, with the observed weight loss of 13.73% and 2.59% corresponding to the release of guest water molecules (calcd 13.96% and 2.58%). Upon further heating, the coordinated lattice water molecules are removed and organic ligands start to decompose in steps from 300 to 800 °C. The thermogravimetric analysis data for compounds 1−3 show that DMF and water guest molecules can be removed at around 300 °C while maintaining the overall framework integrity.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stability of compounds 1-3 has been evaluated ( Figure S5). For compound 1, it shows the first mass loss of 1.41% below 143 °C that can be attributed to the removal of water molecules (calcd 1.50%). Upon further heating, a two-step weight loss was observed: an initial weight loss of 24.24% from 143 to 330 °C that can be associated with the release of DMF molecules. The second weight loss occurs between 330 and 600 °C (50.02%) and is attributed to partial organic ligand decomposition (calcd 57.78%). The final release at 800 °C of 20.95% is attributed to the formation of ZnO as confirmed by XRD analysis. Compounds 2-3 show similar thermal behaviors. The TG curves exhibit an initial weight loss finishing at 250 °C for 2 and 3, with the observed weight loss of 13.73% and 2.59% corresponding to the release of guest water molecules (calcd 13.96% and 2.58%). Upon further heating, the coordinated lattice water molecules are removed and organic ligands start to decompose in steps from 300 to 800 °C. The thermogravimetric analysis data for compounds 1-3 show that DMF and water guest molecules can be removed at around 300 °C while maintaining the overall framework integrity.

elements.content: The fluorescence properties of the three as-synthesized compounds and their respective ligands were evaluated in solid state at room temperature upon excitation at 380 nm. As shown in Figure a, compounds 1−2 exhibit intensive blue luminescence emissions at 433 nm and 440 nm, respectively, which are slightly blue-shifted from the 470 nm emission of the free ligand, 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid. A similar blue shift was observed in the case of compound 3, with emission at 441 nm; the 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid free ligand emits around 469 nm. The observed blue-shift for the three compounds from the H3PyImDC ligand emission can be due to an intraligand π−π* transition. The observed enhanced luminescence intensity can be attributed to the strong interactions between the deprotonated H3PyImDC ligands and the metal center, which imparts the rigidity of H3PyImDC and reduces the nonradioactive loss.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties

The fluorescence properties of the three as-synthesized compounds and their respective ligands were evaluated in solid state at room temperature upon excitation at 380 nm. As shown in Figure a, compounds 1-2 exhibit intensive blue luminescence emissions at 433 nm and 440 nm, respectively, which are slightly blue-shifted from the 470 nm emission of the free ligand, 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid. A similar blue shift was observed in the case of compound 3, with emission at 441 nm; the 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid free ligand emits around 469 nm. The observed blue-shift for the three compounds from the H3PyImDC ligand emission can be due to an intraligand π-π* transition. The observed enhanced luminescence intensity can be attributed to the strong interactions between the deprotonated H3PyImDC ligands and the metal center, which imparts the rigidity of H3PyImDC and reduces the nonradioactive loss.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully constructed three novel MOFs with different network topologies and strong fluorescence properties from the assembly of H3PyImDC ligands and zinc or neodymium ions. Tunable modification of the H3ImDC ligand with a pyridyl group has permitted the access of two H3PyImDC ligands, which then served as T-shaped tripodal linkers for the construction of three novel compounds. Compounds 1 and 3 are 3D frameworks with novel bbm and ant network topologies, respectively. Future research will focus on constructing new metal organic materials (MOMs) based on the assembly of different types of metal centers with H3PyImDC ligands; the spatial effect of the substituent groups will also be evaluated.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have successfully constructed three novel MOFs with different network topologies and strong fluorescence properties from the assembly of H3PyImDC ligands and zinc or neodymium ions. Tunable modification of the H3ImDC ligand with a pyridyl group has permitted the access of two H3PyImDC ligands, which then served as T-shaped tripodal linkers for the construction of three novel compounds. Compounds 1 and 3 are 3D frameworks with novel bbm and ant network topologies, respectively. Future research will focus on constructing new metal organic materials (MOMs) based on the assembly of different types of metal centers with H3PyImDC ligands; the spatial effect of the substituent groups will also be evaluated.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·4H2O (0.10 mmol), 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (0.05 mmol), piperazine [0.1 mL, 0.58 M in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF)], HNO3 (0.1 mL, 0.35 M in DMF), and 2 mL of DMF/H2O (1:1) was sealed in a 20 mL vial and heated at 115 °C for 8 h. Colorless block crystals were collected (63% yield based on Zn(NO3)2·4H2O). Elemental analysis (wt %) for 1. Calcd: C, 42.03; H, 3.78; N, 15.17; Zn, 16.35. Found: C, 41.96; H, 3.63; N, 15.34; Zn, 16.20. FT-IR (4000−600 cm−1): 3389, 3059, 1715, 1633, 1485, 1462, 1351, 1280, 1234, 1064, 1012, 940, 697.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>2</bold>

A mixture of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.18 mmol), 2-(pyridine-4-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (0.25 mmol), KOH (0.06 mL, 8.03 M in H2O), and 4 mL H2O was sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 140 °C for 96 h. Polyhedral pink crystals were collected (62% yield based on Nd(NO3)3·6H2O). Elemental analysis (wt %) for 2. Calcd: C, 29.41; H, 2.96; N, 11.43; Nd, 23.55. Found: C, 29.22; H, 2.89; N, 11.34; Nd, 23.48. FT-IR (4000−600 cm−1): 3394, 3126, 1726, 1662, 1560, 1486, 1375, 1274, 1124, 1066, 1016, 843, 748, 712.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>3</bold>

A mixture of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.09 mmol), 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (0.125 mmol), KOH (0.02 mL, 8.03 M in H2O), and 6 mL of H2O was sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 120 h. Polyhedral pink crystals were collected (68% yield Nd(NO3)3·6H2O). Elemental analysis (wt %) for 3. Calcd: C, 34.50; H, 1.66;N, 12.07; Nd, 31.08. Found: C, 34.32; H, 1.57; N, 12.15; Nd, 31.04. FT-IR (4000−600 cm−1): 3384, 3083, 1725, 1652, 1546, 1481, 1373, 1292, 1211, 1114, 1064, 1018, 850, 779, 723, 680.

FT-IR (4000-600 cm-1): 3384, 3083, 1725, 1652, 1546, 1481, 1373, 1292, 1211, 1114, 1064, 1018, 850, 779, 723, 680.

cln_elements.content: The thermal stability of compounds 1−3 has been evaluated ( Figure S5). For compound 1, it shows the first mass loss of 1.41% below 143 °C that can be attributed to the removal of water molecules (calcd 1.50%). Upon further heating, a two-step weight loss was observed: an initial weight loss of 24.24% from 143 to 330 °C that can be associated with the release of DMF molecules. The second weight loss occurs between 330 and 600 °C (50.02%) and is attributed to partial organic ligand decomposition (calcd 57.78%). The final release at 800 °C of 20.95% is attributed to the formation of ZnO as confirmed by XRD analysis. Compounds 2−3 show similar thermal behaviors. The TG curves exhibit an initial weight loss finishing at 250 °C for 2 and 3, with the observed weight loss of 13.73% and 2.59% corresponding to the release of guest water molecules (calcd 13.96% and 2.58%). Upon further heating, the coordinated lattice water molecules are removed and organic ligands start to decompose in steps from 300 to 800 °C. The thermogravimetric analysis data for compounds 1−3 show that DMF and water guest molecules can be removed at around 300 °C while maintaining the overall framework integrity.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stability of compounds 1-3 has been evaluated ( Figure S5). For compound 1, it shows the first mass loss of 1.41% below 143 °C that can be attributed to the removal of water molecules (calcd 1.50%). Upon further heating, a two-step weight loss was observed: an initial weight loss of 24.24% from 143 to 330 °C that can be associated with the release of DMF molecules. The second weight loss occurs between 330 and 600 °C (50.02%) and is attributed to partial organic ligand decomposition (calcd 57.78%). The final release at 800 °C of 20.95% is attributed to the formation of ZnO as confirmed by XRD analysis. Compounds 2-3 show similar thermal behaviors. The TG curves exhibit an initial weight loss finishing at 250 °C for 2 and 3, with the observed weight loss of 13.73% and 2.59% corresponding to the release of guest water molecules (calcd 13.96% and 2.58%). Upon further heating, the coordinated lattice water molecules are removed and organic ligands start to decompose in steps from 300 to 800 °C. The thermogravimetric analysis data for compounds 1-3 show that DMF and water guest molecules can be removed at around 300 °C while maintaining the overall framework integrity.
